Subject: Re: [neat] Bilateral Symmetry and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=woxkREElUXErXwVdIWyLYdGOGvPmftmCTgw3aAuR-yPWbWuohA

> Well, then the answer to the question: To what
> extent is symmetry necessary?
> Might be: Not at all.
> However, point taken.  "Useful" might be a better
> term than "necessary".
> >Note that there are different ways that the domain
> >symmetry could be relevent:
> >
> >no symmetry
> >bilateral symmetric agent in asymetric world (most
> >common)
> 
> Why would you say this is the most common?  Plenty
> of experimental domains
> (many of which we've discussed here) have some form
> of symmetry inherent in
> the task, if not bilateral symmetry.  In what cases
> would there not be *any*
> symmetry in the "world"?  I would think it would be
> much more common,
> especially if the domain involves something like an
> embodied agent in a
> simulated world, for there to be a high degree of
> symmetry in the
> environment.

OK, it depends what one means by "symmetry".

What I said this was most common I was thinking of
bilaterally symmetric agents which were embedded in
some sort of world where they can rotate/translate
etc.

I now realise I'm discussing two different types of
symmetry here:

1) the agent is "functionally symmetric" - turn left
is the mirror image of turn right and seeing something
on the left is the mirror image of seeing same thing
on the left (or at least the mirror image of that
thing :)

2) the world "has rich symmetries" in that _its_rules_
are translationally and rotationally invariant (every
point in the world is "just like" every other, every
direction likewise).

3) however the world is not bilaterally symmetrical,
e.g. there is no reason why the right half of the data
should be the mirror-image of the left half, and even
if it was, the symmetry won't survive the first few
times the agent moves (the world being viewed from the
agent, so the agent has to be the center of symmetry)

> >Presumably it is totally necessary, otherwise you
> have
> >two separate neural nets...?
> 
> RE: contralateral connectivity...well, that's why I
> want to know to what
> extent it is necessary.  There are human patients
> who have their corpus
> callosum (the main bundle of nerves connecting the
> hemispheres) severed, who
> function almost completely normally.

They route intra-hemisphere communications via
roundabout routes.  e.g. even through the world, like
if you show one eye a picture and ask the patient what
it is, making them reply in some manner than needs the
other hemisphere, then they can't answer, but if you
left the first hemisphere answer first, then ask the
other one, then it will know, because it listened to
the first one's answer.

Personally I think this falls into the well-known
catagory of scientific phenomena known as "oo -
creapy"...

>  I have read of
> experiments with
> locomotion (maybe I talked about them in an earlier
> mail), where neural
> networks controlling paired legs are completely
> decoupled (that is, they
> aren't connected at all).  So contralateral
> connectivity may be crucial for
> some tasks, or possibly irrelevant for many others.

That's exactly the same phnomena as I was
mentioning...

> I see that some of your questions were answered
> later, but some were
> not...I'll get to the ones that weren't later.
> 
> >Isn't this last sentance a bit odd, e.g. if you
> insert
> >a node into a translateral connection, then if the
> two
> >new connections are both translateral, the overall
> >effect is lateral (connecting right->left->right)?
> Very observant. :)  Yes, the result of a neuron
> mutation on symmetrical,
> contralateral connections between two symmetrical
> neurons are two new
> incoming contralateral connections to the two new
> neurons, and two new
> outgoing contralateral connections from the two new
> neurons.  The
> alternative to this would have been to have either
> the incoming or outgoing
> be contralateral and the other pair of connections
> be ipsilateral.
> To be honest, this was a special case, and we
> weren't entirely sure the best
> way to handle it, so we implemented it so that there
> are four new
> connections that are all contralateral.
> 
> >Ah! I see the answer to my previous question, so if
> I
> >read you correctly, you are specifying the nodes in
> a
> >"pre-symmetry" format, and then adding symmetry
> during
> >network creation according to the symmetry flag on
> the
> >node-gene. But for the connections you are
> specifying
> >their source and target neurons from the
> post-symmetry
> >pool?
> >
> >That seems like a very odd choice to me. I had
> >assumed up to this point that the node and
> connection
> >genes were both "pre-symmetry" and that you were
> >creating the symmetry of the connections are
> network
> >creation time as well.
> 
> I'm not sure what you mean by "pre-symmetry". 
> Basically every gene has a
> symmetry attribute, so whether or not a given neuron
> or connection is
> symmetrical or asymmetrical is completely determined
> by the genetic
> encoding.
> 
> >With regard to your current scheme, suppose you
> have
> >two nodes:
> >
> >1 - hidden, symmetric
> >
> >2- hidden, symmetric
> >
> >at network creation time these become:
> >
> >1left 1right
> >
> >
> >2left 2right
> 
> Okay, good so far.
> 
> >And connection genes can separately specify that
> they
> >are 1left to 2left, or 1right to 2right...
> 
> Yesï¿½
> 
> >But not 1 left to 2right? err, actually I don't get
> >what you mean, there seems to be some ambiguity in
> how
> >the connection gene targets and flags interact...
> 
> No, a connection gene can specify for 1left to
2right.
> That would be a connection gene with symmetry=left
and 
> lateralization=contra.  Symmetry type for a
connection 
> determines its source neuron, and lateralization 
> determines whether it crosses the midline.

Ah!  I get it, the values for the "symmetry flag" in
the connection gene are:

"left", "right" or "both"

not:

"true" or "false" as I imagined....

It seems a little odd to me that you support asymetric
connections between symmetric nodes.  e.g. are you
open to the case where no symmetric network can
develop because the presence of any asymmetric link
renders it unsuited to a symmetric task?

I guess, however, when you do the experiments you will
turn the probability of "assymetry within symmetry" up
and down, as a way of measuring how much the symmetric
options are contributing?  I think you even said
somthing about that...

	Ian
